title: Travel briefs
text:
Columbus, Ohio • Aug 30, 2015 • 83° Broken Clouds The Columbus Dispatch Need help? Visit our FAQ page or use our Contact Form . Customer Service Need help? Newsroom Use our Contact Form , or call 614-461-5200. Dispatch Careers Visit dispatch.com/careers or call 614-461-5033. Fax 614-461-5565. Sunday August 30, 2015 5:00 AM Stargazing to be taught 
The Cincinnati Observatory will offer an introductory astronomy course on Wednesday and on Sept. 9. 
The program is designed for beginners who want to learn more about observing the night sky. 
Participants will learn how to identify stars, constellations and planets and get tips on viewing the moon. Each night, weather permitting, will include viewing through the observatory’s historic telescopes. 
The cost is $30 a person. To register or learn more, call 513-321-5186. Statues surface in Paris 
Two giant Egyptian statues and a temple slab submerged in the Mediterranean Sea for more than a millennium have gone on display at Paris’ Arab World Institute. 
The museum erected the granite monuments as a preview of its exhibition “Osiris: Mysteries of Submerged Egypt,” which will open Sept. 8. The show will feature almost 300 artifacts, most of them discovered through underwater excavations by French marine archaeologist Frank Goddio. 
Goddio and his team discovered the underwater ruins of the ancient cities of Canopus in 1997 and Thonis-Heracleion in 2000. The cities sank into the Mediterranean during the eighth century after a series of natural disasters. 
Goddio oversaw the raising of statues of the Egyptian gods Osiris and Isis, and the slab, known as a stele, that sat at the front of a temple. Each is about 20 feet tall. Erie Canal lock promoted 
New York state is planning a living-history rest area near an Erie Canal lock along a stretch of I-90 near Albany. 
The facility, which will open in the fall, will include a visitors center adjacent to Lock E-13 on the Mohawk River in the Montgomery County town of Root. 
The rest area will offer tourism information and interpretive displays showcasing the region’s history. Clothes make the exhibit 
More than 200 years’ worth of fashion choices, from frock coats to mini-dresses, are on display at the South Carolina State Museum in Columbia. 
The exhibition, “Threads: The Story in Our Clothes,” tells the diverse histories of South Carolinians through their clothing. It examines why people wore what they did and what role society, fashion, the environment and practicality played in that.
